head.title: National Briefing | South: Kentucky: Indictment Issued In Fen-Phen Settlement

hedline.hl1: National Briefing | South: Kentucky: Indictment Issued In Fen-Phen Settlement

abstract.p: Indictment for wire fraud issued in Covington, Ky, says that lawyers William J Gallion, Shirley A Cunningham Jr and Melbourne Mills Jr illegally kept $65 million in settlement money that should have been distributed to their clients; money is part of $200 million settlement of civil suit claiming that about 440 people had been injured by diet drug fen-phen (S)

block.p: Three Lexington lawyers illegally kept $65 million in settlement money that should have been distributed to their clients, according to an indictment for wire fraud issued by a federal grand jury in Covington. The money was part of $200 million settlement of a civil suit claiming that about 440 people had been injured by the diet drug fen-phen. The lawyers, William J. Gallion, Shirley A. Cunningham Jr. and Melbourne Mills Jr., were entitled to about a third of the settlement but took twice that, the indictment said. The lawyers have denied criminal wrongdoing.

Correction: June 16, 2007, Saturday A sports article yesterday about two lawyers indicted in Kentucky on federal charges of conspiring to defraud clients in a $200 million lawsuit settlement with the maker of the diet drug fen-phen omitted the name of a third lawyer who was indicted. Melbourne Mills Jr. was also charged -- but unlike the other two, Shirley A. Cunningham Jr. and William J. Gallion, he was not a part-owner of the Preakness champion Curlin. (Unaware of the sports article, the editors of the National Briefing column ran another one that omitted the lawyers' horse-owning backgrounds.)
